prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

head.label.name: ยง
head.headtext: Access to Duplication and Transmission Equipment

para.paratext: Much of modern technology is vulnerable to invasion by unauthorized third parties. This includes message retrieval systems, modems, cellular and other mobile phones, speaker or conference phones, and other developing technology. Thus, special attention should be paid to security in relation to the transmission of information using technology. While training and preparation will help to prevent accidental disclosure of confidential information, it is just as important to avoid becoming the target of industrial espionage tactics. In recent years, the following methods, among others, have been used to obtain secret business information:
third parties accessing internal computer systems;
audio or video surveillance, including tapping and bugging devices; and
unauthorized access to message systems such as electronic mail, voice mail and answering machines.

Security measures are particulary important in areas where data is transmitted by electronic means such as facsimile. Access to facsimile machines, computers and phones should be limited, in appropriate circumstances, through the use of passwords or other barriers. When confidential documents are sent to anyone outside the business, a cover letter or fax cover sheet should be included. The cover letter or sheet should be addressed to a specific person and contain appropriate instructions and warnings to both intended and unintended recipients.
